awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Reasons for Rarity? Exploring Acclimatory and Adaptive Constraints to Commonness
awd_abstract_narration:
In the natural world all species are not represented equally. That is, while some species are common, others are rare. Scientists do not fully understand why such differences in the abundance of species exist and in particular how rare species can continue to persist.  As the natural world is dynamic, in order to persist, species must successfully respond to the environmental changes they experience. Possible ways to do this include adaptation and acclimation. Adaptation involves a genetic change in a population over generations. This ability to adapt is influenced by the variation found within a population and this variation may be limited for rare species, which often are found in small numbers. Acclimation involves the ability of an individual within its life-time to adjustment to different conditions. Acclimation may be especially important in the face of rapid environmental change because adaptation takes time. This study will examine how common and rare plant species adapt and acclimate to environmental change to understand how each can persist. The results of this study will help guide the conservation of rare species and will foster collaborations among researchers at botanical gardens and several undergraduate focused universities. This research will support student experiential learning, as well as the mentoring and inclusion of students from underrepresented groups in the natural sciences and community colleges. Finally, this project will also engage the public through science cafés and outreach opportunities at botanical gardens.

The question of why some species are rare while others are common is enduring and has important implications for ecological theory, the conservation of rare species, and the understanding of biodiversity patterns. This study will use a multi-faceted approach to address why some species are rare while others are common. First, to assess the potential acclimatory and adaptive constraints associated with the commonness of species, laboratory experiments using controlled-environments, as well as field surveys, will be conducted to compare the genetic diversity and ecophysiological plasticity found within and across a suite of rare endemic and common congeneric plant species. Second, to frame empirical investigations and understand the traits associated with plant rarity, a comprehensive synthesis of the existing primary literature will be conducted. And third, to predict the performance and persistence of rare species, empirically derived trait and plasticity based data will be used to develop mechanistic trait-based models. The collaborative research efforts supported by this study will provide a deeper conceptual understanding of species rarity and guidance for conservation efforts.

por.por_cntn:
Many plant species on Earth are rare, owing to restricted geographic ranges, habitat specialization, and/or small local population sizes. It is of great interest to know why some species are rare, while other species are widespread or common.  Especially intriguing is the fact that sometimes a rare species even has a very close relative that is widespread.  Determining characteristics that are correlated with rarity can aid in the protection efforts for rare species.  In this project, we investigated the ecological and evolutionary causes and consequences of rarity through a series of growth chamber and field experiments, and a meta-analysis of relevant studies published over the past 45 years.  Our research compared the genetic diversity, fitness, and certain physical and physiological features (phenotypes) of rare plant species with their closely-related widespread relatives to examine possible reasons for rarity. Rare species are expected to have lower genetic diversity due to small population sizes and/or limited distributions. Lack of genetic variability in a species could constrain its ability to adapt to changing environmental conditions. Also, highly specialized rare species are expected to have limited fitness outside of their specific habitat type. However, individuals of many plant species are able to modify their growth under different environmental conditions; for example, changing leaf sizes or the amount of root material if the environment becomes sunnier, or hotter, or drier. This flexibility in growth patterns is called “phenotypic plasticity”. We hypothesized that ample phenotypic plasticity could allow a species to become more widespread throughout a range of environments, whereas the lack of phenotypic plasticity could explain why some species are rare and restricted to a small region or a very specific type of habitat.

In our experimental studies, we compared six pairs of rare and widespread species, with both members of a pair always from the same genus. The six genera were Pityopsis, Boechera, Xyris, Helianthus, Echinacea, and Scutellaria.  We collected seeds from several populations throughout the natural range of each species and grew the plants in growth chambers that were programmed for different levels of light, temperature, and soil moisture.  At the end of the experiment, plant growth under these different environmental conditions was quantified for various physical features such as leaf size, root length, biomass, etc.  The genetic variability of the plants used in the experiment was also compared for each rare/widespread species pair. Additionally, we conducted a field common garden experiment with the two Pityopsis species to compare fitness, traits, and plasticity under those conditions.

While we are still completing analyses for some of these species pairs, we have published results from two species pairs (Pityopsis, Boechera), and have observed interesting trends in the analyses of the others. We expected genetic variability to be lower for the rare species of each rare/widespread species pair.  We have found this to be generally true when combining data for the species as a whole, although not always at the individual population level since genetic variability can vary from higher to lower for different populations of the same species -- for example, if different populations have different methods of reproduction, such as seems to be the case for the widespread Boechera species. Contrary to expectations, we have not seen strong evidence that widespread species have greater phenotypic plasticity than rare species under the different environmental conditions tested.

            To complement our experimental work, we conducted a large meta-analysis, in which we synthesized results from 153 peer-reviewed published studies from 1978-2020 and one of our manuscripts that was then under review. This synthesis contrasted the population genetic diversity, fitness, and functional traits of 252 rare species and 267 common congeners. We identified several key patterns that emerged across these publications. For one, common species harbor significantly more genetic diversity than their rare counterparts. Furthermore, relative to their common congeners, rare species have lower fitness, smaller flowers and fruits, and could suffer from inbreeding depression or reduced efficiency of fertilization. Our quantitative synthesis of the literature also revealed persistent gaps in our understanding of species rarity. We advocate for more experimental studies in the native field locations in which rare species evolve, especially in understudied tropical biodiversity hotspots. These field studies should explore quantitative genetic variance and adaptive phenotypic plasticity, especially in the context of rapid global change. Discerning reasons for rarity is challenging but could advance our theoretical understanding of species’ rarity and improve planning for the conservation of rare species and overall biodiversity against the pressures of contemporary environmental change.

Faculty from several different academic institutions collaborated and broadened their skills throughout this research project.  Furthermore, numerous students (graduate and undergraduate) participated and thus were trained in relevant scientific skills, preparing them for more advanced studies and future employment. A majority were from groups under-represented in the field of science, such as women and first generation college students.
